questions.question: A 28-year-old female presents with a painless, bluish, fluctuant and translucent swelling on the lower lip that enlarges with eating or pressure, as shown in the image below. She reports a history of accidentally biting her lip frequently. What histopathological feature would be expected on biopsy of the lesion?

options.A: Mucin-filled cavity surroundedby granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells.
options.B: Proliferation of ductal cells within fibrous connective tissue
options.D: Eosinophilic granuloma with multinucleated giant cells

questions.explanation: cells. Correct Answer: A) Mucin-filled cavity surrounded by granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells. Explanation: The clinical presentation and the image suggest Mucocele, a benign cystic lesion caused by the accumulation of saliva due to trauma or obstruction of the salivary gland duct. Histologically, it is characterized by a mucin-filled cavity without an epithelial lining (in the extravasation type), surrounded by granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells , especially macrophages (mucinophages). Retention cysts show a t rue cyst lined by ductal epithelium. Treatment Cryotherapy : Freezing the cyst with extreme cold to destroy it. Laser Treatment : Using a laser to remove the lesion. Surgical Excision : Removing the cyst and possibly the affected salivary gland.

questions.question: A 40-year-old female presents with a slowly growing painless mass in her left parotid gland region that has been present for several months. On examination, a firm, mobile, non-tender mass is palpable in the preauricular area. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) reveals epithelial and myoepithelial cells in a chondromyxoid background. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pleomorphic adenoma Explanation: Type of tumour Nature of the tumour HPE features Pleomorphic adenoma Benign/ Malignant Mixed tumor with ductal and myoepithelial cells Warthin tumour Benign Oncocytic cells with double-layered lining Mucoepidermoid carcinoma Low to intermediate malignant potential Mucinous and squamous epithelial cells, variable cystic spaces Adenoid cystic carcinoma Intermediate to high-grade malignant Cribriform pattern, perineural invasion

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless, slowly growing mass in her left parotid gland. Examination reveals a firm, mobile mass. Biopsy confirms pleomorphic adenoma with characteristic islands of cartilage and foci of bone in a myxoid stroma. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

options.A: Mostly found in the parotid gland
options.B: Mixed tumours with ductal, myoepithelial and mesenchymal cells
options.C: Radiation exposure is a risk factor
options.D: Down-regulation of PLAG1 results in abnormal cell proliferation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Down-regulation of PLAG1 results in abnormal cell proliferation PLAG1 (pleomorphic adenoma gene 1) is a proto-oncogene whose overexpression is a crucial oncogenic event in salivary gland pleomorphic adenomas. Due to chromosomal rearrangements in pleomorphic adenoma, there is overexpression of PLAG1 (transcription factor) resulting in increased cell growth and increased proliferation. Hence, down-regulation of PLAG 1 does not happen in pleomorphic adenoma. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page 748

questions.question: A 55-year-old male has a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the left parotid gland over several years. Examination reveals a firm, mobile, non-tender mass. Histological findings confirm pleomorphic adenoma. Which factor is associated with an increased risk of malignant transformation in pleomorphic adenomas?

options.D: Presence of hyalinized stroma within the tumour

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Increased age of the lesion. Explanation: Rates of malignant transformation in pleomorphic adenoma correlate with the age of the lesion; 2% of tumours that have been present for less than 5 years harbor cancers, but this increases to 10% for those present for more than 15 years. Risk factors of pleomorphic adenoma Age : Higher incidence in older individuals, especially over 50. Smoking : Increased risk with a history of more than 10 pack-years. Radiation Exposure : Previous head and neck radiation therapy or occupational exposure. Chemical Exposure : Contact with chemicals in rubber manufacturing, asbestos mining, or plumbing. Diet : High cholesterol intake may contribute. Sex : More common in females. Reference: Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 748

questions.question: A 50-year-old male smoker presents with a painless swelling in the parotid region. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) reveals murky fluid. Which of the following histopathological features is true regarding this condition?

options.A: Proliferation of squamous epithelial cells with keratinisation

questions.explanation: cystadenoma lymphomatosum , a benign salivary gland tumour that typically occurs in the parotid gland. It is characterized by oncocytic cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, double-layered epithelial lining (bilayered epithelial lining) and lymphoid stroma. This characteristic appearance is often referred to as "Cystic oncocytic hyperplasia."

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Warthin's tumour is true?

options.A: It is the most common malignant tumour of the salivary glands.
options.B: They are typically located in the parotid gland.
options.C: It is more common in females.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer : B) They Are typically located in the parotid gland. Explanation: Warthin tumour or Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, a benign salivary gland tumour primarily affecting the parotid gland. It is more common in males and is strongly associated with a history of smoking. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 751

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with a slow-growing painless mass in the left submandibular gland region. Imaging studies reveal a solid lesion with cystic components. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) shows a mixture of mucin-producing, epidermoid, and intermediate cells. A histopathology image is given below. Which of the following features is true regarding this condition?

options.A: Most commonly found in the sublingual salivary glands.
options.B: Most are associated with a (11;19) translocation.
options.D: Histologically characterized by the presence of spindle cells

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Most are associated with a (11;19) translocation. Explanation: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC) is the most common malignant tumour of salivary glands, often found in parotid and minor glands. It is associated with the (11;19) chromosomal translocation, creating CRTC1-MAML2 fusion protein. Histologically, it exhibits squamous and mucous cell features. Based on cellular characteristics and behavior, it is classified into a low, intermediate, or high grade. Image: Low-power view showing sheets and micro cysts containing cells of varying morphologies in Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with a slowly enlarging painless mass in the right parotid gland region. Imaging studies reveal a solid tumour with a characteristic "Swiss cheese" appearance on MRI. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) shows basaloid cells with cribriform and tubular patterns. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.A: Most commonly occur in the parotid and submandibular glands.
options.B: MYB-NFIB gene rearrangements are present in all cases
options.C: Encapsulated lesions with a smooth surface.
options.D: Tend to grow rapidly and have a high mitotic rate.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Most commonly occur in the parotid and submandibular glands. Explanation: The clinical presentation and characteristic ‘Swiss cheese’ appearance on MRI with basaloid cells and cribriform pattern on FNAC suggest Adenoid cystic carcinoma, which most commonly affects parotid and submandibular glands. 50% of these relatively uncommon tumours occur in the minor salivary glands. Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma (ACC) Incidence and Sites : 50% occur in minor salivary glands (e.g., palatine glands). Also found in parotid and submandibular glands , and extraglandular sites (nose, sinuses, lung, breast). Pathogenesis : Associated with MYB-NFIB gene rearrangements in some cases. Morphology : Gross : Small, poorly encapsulated, infiltrative, gray-pink lesions. Microscopic : Cribriform ("Swiss cheese") pattern with hyaline-filled spaces. Other patterns: tubular and solid. Small cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. Slow-growing but highly invasive, often showing perineural invasion . Frequently recurs and disseminates to distant sites (bone, liver, brain) even decades later. MYB-NFIB gene rearrangements are present in all cases (Option B) MYB-NFIB gene rearrangements are present in a subset of adenoid cystic carcinomas and not in all cases. Encapsulated lesions with a smooth surface (Option C) Adenoid cystic carcinomas are small, poorly encapsulated, infiltrative, gray-pink lesions composed of small cells with dark, compact nuclei and scant cytoplasm. The tumour cells are organized in a cribriform growth pattern that resembles Swiss cheese. Tend to grow rapidly and have a high mitotic rate (Option D) Adenoid cystic carcinomas are slow-growing tumours that tend to invade perineural spaces, indicating a low mitotic rate. Image: Three typical growth patterns, including cribriform (left), tubular (center), and solid (right).
